By Kalbana Perimbanayagam - April 11, 2017 @ 12:44amKUALA LUMPUR: Pas is set to hold a demonstration outside the headquarters of Chinese-language daily Nanyang Siang Pau for running a derogatory cartoon on the party in its newspaper.The demonstration, organised by Selangor Pas Youth Council, will be held at Nanyang's Petaling Jaya headquarters in Petaling Jaya at 11am.A memorandum of protest is expected to be handed over by Pas reps to the publication.It is understood that the protest will go ahead despite the newspaper having already issued an apology over the offending cartoon.The cartoon depicted two monkeys on a tree, with one of the monkeys wearing a headgear (serban), supposedly resembling the party.The cartoon is said to be poking fun at Pas president Datuk Seri Abdul Hadi Awang's tabling of a Private Member's Bill to increase the powers of the Syariah Courts, in Parliament last week.Pas information chief Nasrudin Hassan said the party is offended and insulted by the cartoon which appeared in the newspaper. He said Pas will not hesitate to take legal action against the publication."This very rude and simply too much. Nanyang Siang Pau should retract the cartoon published in their daily and apologise to all Muslims, especially to Pas, for publishing such an insulting cartoon."This is shallow and uncivilised politics. We are seriously considering taking legal action against the publication," he said in a statement today.He claimed that in the drawing, the publication had likened Parliament speaker Tan Sri Pandikar Amin Mulia to a monkey which jumped of the tree, since he had postponed the RUU 355 debate to the next Dewan Rakyat sitting."You have the right to disagree but not to this extent, " he said.Nasrudin said the drawing also had the word 'RUU 355' and several Mandarin characters, which he assumed described the situation in the Dewan Rakyat last Thursday, when Hadi Awang tabled the Bill.The RUU 355 issue has been an ongoing campaign by Pas and it was only last year that the party was allowed to bring the proposed amendments to the Syariah Courts to Parliament.http://www.enanyang.my/news/20170410/%E9%8...90%AF%E4%BA%8B/NanYang's Apology NewsletterFor those interesting in regards to the imageit is this: Google : ???“?” find cache» Click to show Spoiler - click again to hide... «Speaker : Left the building saying *Leave it to next discussion*.Awang Hadi : trying to have a meal of steamed yam/potato? same old SOPhttp://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/...uslims-or-else/Stop provoking Muslims, or else…GEORGE TOWN: Non-Muslims must stop provoking Malays and Muslims in the country, a Muslim-interest group said today, warning that doing so could very well result in a militant-style reaction from them someday. Jaringan Muslimin Pulau Pinang chairman Mohd Hafiz Noordin was commenting on Nanyang Siang Pau’s publication of a cartoon lampooning PAS president Abdul Hadi Awang and Dewan Rakyat Speaker Pandikar Amin Mulia, which he said appeared to show non-Muslims as wanting to “bertumbuk” (spar) with the Muslim community. Titled “Monkey Show Act”, the cartoon satirised Hadi and Pandikar by depicting them as monkeys on a tree labelled Act 355, which referred to a private member’s bill to amend the Syariah Courts (Criminal Jurisdiction) Act 1965. He said that while it was deplorable that some quarters wished to disturb the peace the country had achieved after nearly 60 years of independence, he was thankful that Muslims and Malays had not reacted to the provocation, as they did not believe in “fights or punches”. He said although Muslims could react aggressively against the non-Muslims if they wanted to, they would not resort to such extreme behaviour as this was the month of Rejab, the month of Prophet Muhammad s.a.w., isyrak mihraj. “The prophet would not react in a militant or violent manner, although the reality is non-Muslims in Malaysia … it appears have a militant network of their own,” Hafiz said. Hafiz said the kind of “militancy” non-Muslims engaged in, did not involve the shedding of blood. He said theirs was the kind based on provocation as they wanted to portray Islam as a religion of extremists. “The extremists here, the pelampau kafir, (the true extremists) in our country is the chief editor of Nanyang,” he said, adding that non-Muslims should immediately stop “courting trouble” with the Muslims. When asked to comment on Nanyang’s public apology, Hafiz said, “Sorry is not enough.” He said the damage had been done and the cartoon was a deliberate attempt to provoke the Muslims.Hafiz said Nanyang should be given the harshest penalty as a deterrent to other newspapers, media outlets and social media users against engaging in such acts of provocation against the Muslims. “We cannot gamble with national security. Nanyang must be censured, cancel their licence, permit. “We do not care. Even if Utusan did it, they too must be punished.” Earlier, Hafiz and Gabungan Perwakilan Melayu Pulau Pinang president Mohd Rizuad Aizudin and Gabungan Bela Hak Islam president Mohd Noordin Mohd Nor presented a memorandum to Nanyang’s Penang office here at Weld Quay. Nanyang’s state advertising chief Beh Sok Hooi received the memorandum and told reporters that it would be handed over to their KL headquarters. In the six-point memo, the groups demanded Nanyang’s management sack the editor who approved the publication of the cartoon. Later, the group burnt photocopies of the controversial cartoon with the words “Biadap” (rude) written across it. A DAP logo was also placed in the middle. They later scooped up the ashes of the paper into a bag in a bid to “save the environment”.
